subject: meta-ibm: p10bmc: Add otptool configuration
commitMessage:
meta-ibm: p10bmc: Add otptool configuration

Some addition development details must be managed in this bbappend due
to co-development of the AST2600 and IBM p10bmc designs. IBM did bringup
of secure-boot on pre-production AST2600 silicon and this shaped how the
platform's OTP was configured.

The PEM files represent the public portion of the IBM signing key-pairs
for p10bmc systems. These are included to provide a canonical location
for the production OTP image artifact.

Change-Id: I7caa6cfd5848b1d671ef95f8031b76088673900a
Signed-off-by: Andrew Jeffery <andrew@aj.id.au>

Hi Andrew,
There are two issues need to check with you.
1. Lost to place rsa_pub_oem_dss_key.pem in OTP key directory for OTP image generation
2. Lost to add the follwoing envirables and "private keys" to sing SPL.


Do you try to add the following variables to sign SPL for RoT image.
```
SOCSEC_SIGN_KEY ?= "${WORKDIR}/your private key for SPL sign"
SOCSEC_SIGN_ALGO ?= "RSA4096_SHA512"
```

The private key should be the one of the following public key paire from you OTP config file
```
key": [
            {
                "types": "rsa_pub_oem",
                "key_pem": "rsa_pub_oem_dss_key.pem",
                "offset": "0x40",
                "number_id": 0,
                "sha_mode": "SHA512"
            },
            {
                "types": "rsa_pub_oem",
                "key_pem": "P10BMCAspeedSBPubKey_1.pem",
                "offset": "0x240",
                "number_id": 1,
                "sha_mode": "SHA512"
            },
            {
                "types": "rsa_pub_oem",
                "key_pem": "P10BMCAspeedSBPubKey_2.pem",
                "offset": "0x440",
                "number_id": 2,
                "sha_mode": "SHA512"
            },
            {
                "types": "rsa_pub_oem",
                "key_pem": "P10BMCAspeedSBPubKey_3.pem",
                "offset": "0x640",
                "number_id": 3,
                "sha_mode": "SHA512"
            }
        ]
```

For example:
you can only place one private key of "rsa_pub_oem_dss_key.pem" to SIGN SPL.
Thanks-Jamin
I don't plan on publishing our production private keys, but yes, there's a bug with not correctly installing the private development key into the keys/ directory :)

Hi Andrew,
Did you place this publick key in key directory?
```
FileNotFoundError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: '/data0/jenkins/workspace/ci-openbmc/distro/ubuntu/label/docker-builder/target/p10bmc/build/work/p10bmc-openbmc-linux-gnueabi/u-boot-aspeed-sdk/1_v2019.04+gitAUTOINC+a570745a1a-r0/keys/rsa_pub_oem_dss_key.pem'
```

Hi Andrew

I think that I found the root cause.
If users want to use RSA big endian, users need to set the RSA big endian in OTP JSON file and SOCSEC tool.
```
"data_region": {
        "ecc_region": true,
        "rsa_key_order": "big",
        "key": [
```
By default, RSA is little endian in otptool. However, we changed RSA default endian to “big” in SOCSEC tool.
That is why SOCSEC tool verified your SPL and OTP image failed. 
https://github.com/AspeedTech-BMC/socsec/blob/master/socsec/otptool.py#L1143-L1187 
OTP RSA endian should be changed in OTP config file. There is a “rsa_key_order” parameter which is only supported in AST2600 A3. 
Users can change it to either “big” or “little”. Of course, users should change the consistence RSA endian in socsec tool, too.
This “rsa_key_order” parameter from OTP JOSN config only supports in AST2600 A3.
Users cannot change OTP RSA endian to big in AST2600 A1 and A2. 
Currently, if users OTP configurations file is either A1 or A2, SOCSEC tool always verifies its SPL and OTP failed because its socsec RSA endian is big endian by default except they change to little endian.
Therefore, do we still need to add “production flag” in ASPEED/otptool? 

By the way, otptool support to print otp image for debugging purpose.
https://github.com/AspeedTech-BMC/socsec#print-otp-image  
Do we need to print it in build environment?
Thanks-Jamin

> OTP RSA endian should be changed in OTP config file.

This isn't the approach I can take, as we already have an OTP binary built without the key order being specified, which as you say defaults to little-endian. This binary is deployed in our production builds of some cards, so we will need to change how we're invoking socsec instead.

> There is a “rsa_key_order” parameter which is only supported in AST2600 A3. 
> Users can change it to either “big” or “little”. Of course, users should change the consistence RSA endian in socsec tool, too.

Yes, IBM will need to add arguments to socsec to force little-endian.

> This “rsa_key_order” parameter from OTP JOSN config only supports in AST2600 A3.
> Users cannot change OTP RSA endian to big in AST2600 A1 and A2. 
> Currently, if users OTP configurations file is either A1 or A2, SOCSEC tool always verifies its SPL and OTP failed because its socsec RSA endian is big endian by default except they change to little endian.
> Therefore, do we still need to add “production flag” in ASPEED/otptool? 

This is a separate question. We (IBM) have to use little-endian key ordering now due to having deployed OTP binaries in little-endian mode. In general we can't use this behaviour to infer the A3 vs pre-A3 case.

> 
> By the way, otptool support to print otp image for debugging purpose.
> https://github.com/AspeedTech-BMC/socsec#print-otp-image  
> Do we need to print it in build environment?

It's probably a good idea.

Thanks for root-causing the problem for me.

> > OTP RSA endian should be changed in OTP config file.
> 
> This isn't the approach I can take, as we already have an OTP binary built without the key order being specified, which as you say defaults to little-endian. This binary is deployed in our production builds of some cards, so we will need to change how we're invoking socsec instead.
> 
> > There is a “rsa_key_order” parameter which is only supported in AST2600 A3. 
> > Users can change it to either “big” or “little”. Of course, users should change the consistence RSA endian in socsec tool, too.
> 
> Yes, IBM will need to add arguments to socsec to force little-endian.
> 
> > This “rsa_key_order” parameter from OTP JOSN config only supports in AST2600 A3.
> > Users cannot change OTP RSA endian to big in AST2600 A1 and A2. 
> > Currently, if users OTP configurations file is either A1 or A2, SOCSEC tool always verifies its SPL and OTP failed because its socsec RSA endian is big endian by default except they change to little endian.
> > Therefore, do we still need to add “production flag” in ASPEED/otptool? 
> 
> This is a separate question. We (IBM) have to use little-endian key ordering now due to having deployed OTP binaries in little-endian mode. In general we can't use this behaviour to infer the A3 vs pre-A3 case.
> 
Will discuss with socsec designers.

Once this flag ready, I will add patch to update socsec version in OpenBMC.

> Thanks for root-causing the problem for me.
Can you add something about where these pem files come from and why they're checked in.

This is a change from what we've been using to date, yeah?

Is there a good reason to make this different from what we've been using (and what the other machines that use this in the tree will use)?
No, no change here, we've been running with the stack beyond 64K for quite some time (12 months? Whenever we made the change? Before Klaus went to RH).

> No, no change here, we've been running with the stack beyond 64K for quite some time (12 months? Whenever we made the change? Before Klaus went to RH).

Isn't that the opposite of what the comment says?

No?

> the stack *does not* intersect the 64KiB SRAM region

> --stack_intersects_verification_region=false is also the default now: https://github.com/AspeedTech-BMC/socsec/blob/master/socsec/socsec.py#L1929

Ok. I find the comment confusing. Should we delete the comment and the EXTRA_OPTS if it's the default?

If we did that maybe we could delete the comment with it and solve the confusion, so maybe? I think I put it there so we weren't relying on implicit behaviour, but I don't see it changing in the future.

> If we did that maybe we could delete the comment with it and solve the confusion, so maybe? I think I put it there so we weren't relying on implicit behaviour, but I don't see it changing in the future.

Yep. Lets do that.
mixing append with +=.  Need to pick one or the other - if you go with append don't forget you need a space between the opening quote and f
